You might encounter people who want to cause trouble for no reason, bullies, and thieves. I have been bullied in this neighborhood in the past through physical assault, but that was many years ago. Another recent incident involved package theft. Although common, there are package thieves in this neighborhood. Lastly, although New York City has fines for not cleaning up after dogs, people here don't follow the rules. Every morning, you will see at least one dog waste on your way to the train station or supermarket. My biggest annoyance is dog waste on the ground everywhere I go in this neighborhood. Be careful and keep your shoes clean!

The first thing to understand about Portland, Oregon, is the meaning of "weird." The unofficial town slogan, written on the back of a building that serves as a pizza joint, bar, music venue, and strip club, pushing legal boundaries in at least half of these roles, is "Keep Portland Weird." For some, it's a small call to remember the Portland of the '90s and early 2000s, when the city was less famous and less expensive, fostering creative and unique subcultures. For others, it's an invitation—come to Portland, where being called weird is now a compliment. Despite the influx of wealthy Californians and the constant construction of condos to house them, Portland remains weird. Weird doesn't always mean accepting, but it means being open to things usually not accepted. Weird doesn't mean we lack modern conveniences or struggles. Like the rest of the country, most of our products come from China. There are countless ways to be weird, to be not normal, yet Portland has plenty of normal too. Portland has yoga, hipsters, and business professionals. Perhaps being weird means we just don't take all this too seriously. In my neighborhood, as in many areas of Portland, we have colorful houses, home gardens with flowers, herbs, and vegetables lining the streets, and free boxes in the summer. Free boxes traditionally are cardboard containers with items someone is discarding, but they can also be plastic bags or boxes. They often contain something magical, a perfect treasure for a passerby. Free boxes usually have clothes and books, but can hold anything. The magical potential of strolling through a Southeast Portland neighborhood is what Portland is all about. At least, that's what Portland means to me, but I'm just one of many varieties of weird. Some people around me would never dream of picking clothes out of a box on a sidewalk. Those people go to goat yoga (yes, yoga with real goats) or Timbers matches (the city's soccer team). Portland is full of people who love all sorts of things. It's a city filled with people chasing our dreams, or dreaming of chasing them while spending too much time at bars. Yes, Portland has a drug problem. Drug issues are often rooted in mental health problems, and the constant rain for much of the year, along with gloomy clouds, seems to contribute. Portland also has a homelessness problem, which no one seems to have a solution for. The homeless are drawn by Portland's social services, which are better than most parts of the country, but still insufficient, as is the case nationwide. The non-homeless population wavers between care and resentment. In this aspect, we're not weird at all.

The mountains are always there. In the north, they witness the sun's journey every dawn and dusk. No matter how much I forget about them or how preoccupied I am with work and life, they remain, unwavering and unaffected by life's challenges. On days when I am most stressed and tense, they demand to be seen, and when I turn to them, they allow my anxious soul to rest, lending me strength to continue, one day at a time. I first moved here when I started my undergraduate studies, and it was the mountains to the north of the campus that initially captivated me. Certainly, the university has its own breathtaking sights with buildings, ponds, and trees, which hold a place in my heart, but it is the mountains that truly hold the throne. The rest of the town is beautiful in its unique way. Countless cafés have been home to many hours of caffeine-fueled studying. One can walk or take the bus to the downtown area, where the faded brick walls of restaurants and office buildings create an aura of antiquity. Here, this seemingly suburban town shows as much bustle and vigor as its neighboring city. However, this liveliness doesn't last for many blocks, as one can escape back to the serene small town by passing the library again. This contrast of atmospheres in such close proximity truly gives the city a wondrous vibe, as if beckoning for exploration. It is easy to create cherished memories, each associated with a certain part of town. Whether it's walking past the rusty swings in the park with friends after an all-nighter or running through the busy downtown to catch a movie at the fancy theater for which the university provided tickets. Alas, it is also home to many painful memories, as all places are bound to be in life. The ponds, in particular, are a fitting place for reflection, as well as crying sessions at two in the morning during an existential crisis. I have more experience with the latter. Watching the turtles, ducks, and insects live their lives, each with a role or purpose, I couldn't help but wonder about my own sense of purpose as I struggled to navigate this mystery called life. So, I walked past the pond, past the park and the little houses that scream suburbia, until I reached a main street. It was then that the sun shone its brilliant rays atop the palm trees, painting the sky along the way, and as I looked up at the sunrise, I realized I was walking north. Sure enough, they were there, as they always had been. The sturdy, imposing mountains grazed the hazy blue and yellow sky more than any building on the horizon, and as if speaking without words, they stirred within me a sense of perseverance.

You might overlook it at first glance—after all, it's a residential area behind a shopping strip, not a typical place where people expect to live. At least, it's not where most would choose to reside. However, if you venture past the abandoned Whole Foods and the hotels that open briefly in summer for family reunions, you'll discover a bustling community. Within these neighborhoods, on these streets, are several apartment complexes—arranged like Russian nesting dolls, meticulously dismantled and placed side by side along the road. The first apartments you encounter have been in the news for questionable dealings, so we won't dwell on them too much—appearances can be deceiving, after all. But the apartments next to that complex and the two complexes adjacent to it are a completely different world that almost no locals know about. Across from these complexes is a satellite campus of a community college—quiet buildings standing vigil by the road, where students arrive with coffee in hand, yawning at 7 am to start their sleepy day. The creaky iron gates open to let them in one by one, as commuters grumble at them for causing traffic when attendance is high. The road intersects with another residential street, bordered by a park on one side and a rehabilitation center for people with fractures from unfortunate events. The center boasts cheerful porch furniture and a lazily spinning ceiling fan that stirs the warm summer air. Children run back and forth in the park, tumbling and spinning across the grass, while bees hover lazily around the roadside flowers. Retired folks walk their dogs on the path, frowning at teenagers on skateboards and nodding politely at the teenage girls gossiping by the playground about boys and the latest YouTube stars. There's a sushi place in a strip mall next to the park, offering inexpensive food but never too busy—a swimming supply store is right next to it, and a nail salon snugly fits in between. You could fill your pool, get a manicure, and eat hibachi chicken all at once—the charm of a strip mall. There's also a DIY frozen yogurt place there, and you often see teens in the park holding cold, sweating cups of yogurt covered in toppings, doing stunts on their skateboards and vaping because they think it's the coolest. This neighborhood is a slice of Americana—a piece of history in the sleepy South where almost nothing changes, not even time.

My neighborhood is quite fascinating. Most houses are single-family homes, but some have been divided into two while still being connected, if that makes sense to you. My home has a small yard in front and a narrow driveway to the left. Like most of the others, it evokes a time not long ago when suburban living was the American dream. This dream once seemed to embrace the people of this country, but now it's slipping away. Yet, my neighborhood and many others still stand, still proclaiming to us and visitors that the dream is alive and we are holding onto it as best as we can. People aren't as optimistic as they used to be, and the upkeep of small yards isn't what it once was, but there are still a few cars in every driveway, and the youth still play as if the world around them is all that exists. The public school here, almost 90 years old, still stands, seeming to inspire a future in today's youth while stirring nostalgia in older residents. Churches are few and mostly empty, but the basketball courts remain full. All homes look different but feel the same. There is a large supermarket called Super "A," owned by a large Yemeni family, who may be the only Arab family in the neighborhood. The vast majority of residents are African American. The streets are wide, and kids usually play football, pausing only to let cars pass. Most people in my neighborhood have been here for generations, and most can tell stories of a past where everyone knew everyone. There was a karate school, but when Hollywood stopped making Karate Kid movies, kids stopped wanting to be the karate kid, so it became a pharmacy because drugs supposedly make everything better, or so I've heard. There is also a small movie theater that shows old movies at discounted prices, avoided by the youth for lacking new releases, but cherished by the elders who think it's a small price for a night out, without kids, of course. A single expressway passes through my town, though the exit and entrance are in the neighboring town. There was once a petition to get an exit for our town; the youth supported it, but the elders opposed it. They believed that having the expressway would ruin our town, and eventually persuaded the city council to deny the request. A new high school is being built, and we're deciding on a mascot for our town. I think a cyborg with a country accent and a log cabin would best represent my town.

Since I live in a big city, my neighborhood is incredibly diverse. Residential areas are scattered seemingly at random among commercial areas where various businesses operate. Some of these businesses consist of offices, while others include various shops, restaurants, and entertainment venues. There is no shortage of new restaurants to try or shops to explore. While some stores are large, well-known brands owned by major corporations, small boutiques are also becoming increasingly popular. They are not only located in malls but also line the streets, which are often within walking distance of otherwise quiet and serene neighborhoods, now bustling with activity due to many attractions. There are also a couple of nearby parks, and I have observed that people often visit these parks with their young children. Speaking of people, my neighborhood is quite diverse. In one small area, we have a significant LGBTQ+ community, an Orthodox Jewish community, and a group of refugees and immigrants from the former Soviet Union. Expanding a little beyond my neighborhood, there are individuals of many different races and origins, although they sometimes gather into small communities within the city. We have areas known as Korea Town, Chinatown, Little Armenia, and more, just a few miles away. However, even a few miles can take a long time to drive. Due to traffic, especially during rush hour, driving a distance of 10 miles can sometimes take two hours. Almost no one in my city walks anywhere, though. While some points of interest are inevitably nearby, the city is vast, and people generally do not prefer to commute on foot. As a result, we also have some of the worst traffic in the world, and finding parking spots can be challenging just about anywhere. Ironically, there has been a lot of construction in recent years, with large apartment buildings being added. It seems to be a popular destination, but many residents are disappointed by the prospect of even more people moving in and more vehicles on the roads. However, there are many different types of houses in my city. Not everyone lives, or wants to live, in large apartment buildings. Residential areas consist of houses of various sizes, smaller apartment buildings, and condominiums. Some properties have single-family homes, while others have duplexes. This is true even in my immediate neighborhood, so there is no lack of diversity in housing options either. Similarly, the neighborhood is made up of people of different ages, and honestly, I am not familiar with most of my neighbors. It is not really a close-knit community these days, although I have many childhood memories of playing outside with my next-door neighbor and a few other friends from the neighborhood who were all around my age.

"Where is everything?" she asked as we drove past the endless cornfields stretching to the horizon. "This is it!" I replied, aware she would be shocked by the openness of the landscape. She came from a town where the grocery store was just a five-minute walk from her house—she had never seen so much open space before. Amazed by the endless cornfields, I shared with her what it was like to grow up in rural Ohio. In that moment, she finally understood who I was and where I came from. As we drove down the two-lane country road, we reached a quarry filled with water. Just beyond it lay the small community where I live. The houses are mostly made of brick and stucco. Each home has at least half an acre of land, which everyone takes pride in maintaining. In spring, the gardens are filled with annual flowers and the midwestern trees change with each season. The driveways are lined with high-end Mercedes Benz luxury cars gleaming in the midday sun after a good wash. Continuing down the road toward my gray stucco house, my Korean neighbor is always outside with a friendly smile. He spends his entire day mowing his lawn, singing over the hum of his mower. Everyone in the neighborhood finds him amusing, but he is always genuine and an amazing person with a unique history. As he has aged, he has lost some of his sharpness. He was once a doctor, often blending in with the grass and his John Deere zero-turn mower. Finally, you reach my home. In the side yard, geese are plentiful, chased by our terrier. Out back, there's a small stream flowing into the quarry. Here, you can hear bullfrogs, the stream, and the occasional "moo" from nearby farms. Across the handmade wooden bridge is an untouched oasis filled with naturally growing trees, herbs, and wildflowers. This is where I spent most of my childhood. From building tree forts to 'hunting' animals (which mostly involved chasing them), there was always something to do, and usually a neighborhood child to play with. The winters in my small town can be harsh, yet nothing is more beautiful. The yard transforms from a sea of green into a barren wilderness. The trees that once held vibrant pink, purple, and orange flowers become bare skeletons. When blessed with occasional snowfall, a winter wonderland appears overnight. The backyard is filled with snow angels made by my little sister, and snowmen. My sister and I often fought as kids, and during winter, snowballs were our weapons of choice. We would build massive igloo-like forts to store our weapons, usually using branches as an arsenal. In our own little wonderland, we played pretend where nothing else mattered. We were just carefree kids.
